Consider the chemical reaction a P_4O_{10} + b CaF_2 \rightarrow c PF_5 + d Ca_3(PO_4)_2, where a, b, c, and d are unknown positive integers. The reaction mush be balanced; that is, the number of atoms of each element must be the same before and after the reaction. For example, because the number of oxygen atoms must remain the same, 10a=8d. While there are many possible choices for a, b, c, and d that balance the reaction, it is customary to use the smallest possible integers. Balance this reaction.
Balance the chemical equation
and give your answer in lowest terms. That is, the coefficients should all be integers that do not all share a common factor.

solution.p: SOLUTION: We consider x_1 \mbox{Mn}_{3} \mbox{O}_{9} + x_2 \mbox{H}_{3} \mbox{Cl}_{3} \longrightarrow x_3 \mbox{Mn}_{3} \mbox{Cl}_{9} + x_4 \mbox{H}_{9} \mbox{O}_{3} + x_5 \mbox{Cl}_{9}, which implies \begin{array}{rcrcrcrcrcrcr}3 x_1 \amp \amp \amp - \amp 3 x_{3} \amp \amp \amp \amp \amp \amp \amp = \amp 0 \\9 x_1 \amp \amp \amp \amp \amp - \amp 3 x_{4} \amp \amp \amp \amp \amp = \amp 0 \\ \amp \amp 3 x_{2} \amp \amp \amp - \amp 9 x_{4} \amp \amp \amp \amp \amp = \amp 0 \\ \amp \amp 3 x_{2} \amp - \amp 9 x_{3} \amp \amp \amp - \amp 9 x_{5} \amp \amp \amp = \amp 0\end{array} which has augmented matrix \left[\begin{array}{rrrrrr} 3 \amp 0 \amp -3 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 9 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp -3 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 3 \amp 0 \amp -9 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 3 \amp -9 \amp 0 \amp -9 \amp 0\end{array}\right] Notice that entries of the augmented matrix share a common factor of 3, so that it is row equivalent to the matrix \left[\begin{array}{rrrrrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp -1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 3 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp -1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp -3 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp -3 \amp 0 \amp -3 \amp 0\end{array}\right]. Now row reduce this matrix to get \begin{array}{ccc} \left[\begin{array}{rrrrrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp -1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 3 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp -1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp -3 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp -3 \amp 0 \amp -3 \amp 0\end{array}\right] \amp \overset{-9 R_1 + R_2 \Rightarrow R_2}{\sim} \amp \left[\begin{array}{rrrrrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp -1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 3 \amp -1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp -3 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp -3 \amp 0 \amp -3 \amp 0\end{array}\right] \\ \amp \overset{R_2 \Leftrightarrow R_4}{\sim} \amp \left[\begin{array}{rrrrrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp -1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp -3 \amp 0 \amp -3 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp -3 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 3 \amp -1 \amp 0 \amp 0\end{array}\right] \\ \amp \overset{-R_2 + R_3 \Rightarrow R_3}{\sim} \amp \left[\begin{array}{rrrrrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp -1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp -3 \amp 0 \amp -3 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 3 \amp -3 \amp 3 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 3 \amp -1 \amp 0 \amp 0\end{array}\right] \\ \amp \overset{-R_3 + R_4 \Rightarrow R_4}{\sim} \amp \left[\begin{array}{rrrrrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp -1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp -3 \amp 0 \amp -3 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 3 \amp -3 \amp 3 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 2 \amp -3 \amp 0\end{array}\right] \end{array} We set x_5 = s_1 as a free variable. From row 4, 2 x_4 - 3 s_1 = 0\Rightarrow x_4 = {\frac{3}{2}} s_1. From row 3, 3 x_3 - 3 x_4 + 3 s_1 = 0 \Rightarrow 3 x_3 - 3\left({\frac{3}{2}} s_1\right) +3 s_1 = 0 \Rightarrow x_3 = {\frac{1}{2}} s_1. From row 2 x_2 - 3 x_3 - 3 s_1 = 0 \Rightarrow x_2 - 3 ({\frac{1}{2}} s_1) - 3 s_1 = 0 \Rightarrow x_2 = {\frac{9}{2}} s_1. From row 1, x_1 - x_3 = 0 \Rightarrow x_1 - \left({\frac{1}{2}} s_1\right) = 0 \Rightarrow x_1 = {\frac{1}{2}} s_1. We set s_1 = 2 to obtain x_1 = 1, x_2 = 9, x_3 = 1, x_4 = 3, and x_5 = 2, and the balanced equation is \mbox{Mn}_{3} \mbox{O}_{9}+ 9 \mbox{H}_{3} \mbox{Cl}_{3} \longrightarrow \mbox{Mn}_{3} \mbox{Cl}_{9}+ 3 \mbox{H}_{9} \mbox{O}_{3}+ 2 \mbox{Cl}_{9}.

solution.p: SOLUTION: With the new LAI values, we obtain the three equations using the top three schools \begin{align*} 1482 x_1 + 2699 x_2 + 100 x_3 = 0.7979230 \\ 1481 x_1 + 2776 x_2 + 89 x_3 = 0.7939592 \\ 1408 x_1 + 2616 x_2 + 94 x_3 = 0.7622162 \end{align*} Using a computer algebra system we solve this system and obtain x_1 = 0.0002865, x_2 = 0.0001000, and x_3 = 0.0010343.

statement.p: Use the given LU factorization to find all solutions to \textrm{A}\textbf{x} = \textbf{b}

Find the LU factorization of A= \left[\begin{array}{cc} 5 \amp 5\cr -5 \amp -9 \end{array}\right]. That is, write A=LU where L is a lower triangular matrix with ones on the diagonal, and U is an upper triangular matrix.
For this problem enter matrices using bracket notation. So the matrix
would be entered as [[2,3,-1],[-2,-5,6]].
Find an LU factorization for

solution.p: SOLUTION: \begin{array}{ccccc} \left[\begin{array}{ccc} 6 \amp -7 \amp -5\cr 6 \amp -4 \amp -6\cr 12 \amp -23 \amp -1 \end{array}\right] \amp \overset{\begin{align*} - R_1+ R_2\amp \Rightarrow R_2 \\ -2 R_1+ R_3\amp \Rightarrow R_3 \end{align*}}{\sim} \amp \left[\begin{array}{ccc} 6 \amp -7 \amp -5\cr 0 \amp 3 \amp -1\cr 0 \amp -9 \amp 9 \end{array}\right] \amp \Rightarrow \amp L = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp \mathbf{\cdot} \amp \mathbf{\cdot} \\ 1 \amp 1 \amp \mathbf{\cdot} \\ 2 \amp -3 \amp \mathbf{\cdot} \end{array}\right] \\ \left[\begin{array}{ccc} 6 \amp -7 \amp -5\cr 0 \amp 3 \amp -1\cr 0 \amp -9 \amp 9 \end{array}\right] \amp \overset{\begin{align*} 3 R_2+ R_3\amp \Rightarrow R_3 \end{align*}}{\sim} \amp \left[\begin{array}{ccc} 6 \amp -7 \amp -5\cr 0 \amp 3 \amp -1\cr 0 \amp 0 \amp 6 \end{array}\right] \amp \Rightarrow \amp L = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp \mathbf{\cdot} \amp \mathbf{\cdot} \\ 1 \amp 1 \amp \mathbf{\cdot} \\ 2 \amp -3 \amp 1\end{array}\right] \end{array} Thus L = \left[\begin{array}{ccc} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0\cr 1 \amp 1 \amp 0\cr 2 \amp -3 \amp 1 \end{array}\right] and U = \left[\begin{array}{ccc} 6 \amp -7 \amp -5\cr 0 \amp 3 \amp -1\cr 0 \amp 0 \amp 6 \end{array}\right].

statement.p: If L and U are invertible, then (LU)^{1} = U^{1}L^{1}. Find A^{1} from the given LU factorization:

solution.p: SOLUTION: We have that \begin{align*} A^{-1} = (LU)^{-1} = U^{-1} L^{-1} \amp = \left[\begin{array}{cc} -5 \amp -5\cr 0 \amp 5 \end{array}\right]^{-1} \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1 \amp 0\cr 3 \amp 1 \end{array}\right]^{-1} \\ \amp = \left[\begin{array}{cc} -{\frac{1}{5}} \amp -{\frac{1}{5}} \\ 0 \amp {\frac{1}{5}} \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1 \amp 0 \\ -3 \amp 1 \end{array}\right]\\ \amp = \left[\begin{array}{cc} {\frac{2}{5}} \amp -{\frac{1}{5}} \\ -{\frac{3}{5}} \amp {\frac{1}{5}} \end{array}\right] \end{align*}
